subject: Re: [junit] Re: Conditional tearDown()
msgSnippet: In our programmer integration tests that actually hit an external db, we just made the tearDown implementation never fail. tearDown() is called after each
messageBody:
In our programmer integration tests that actually hit an external db,
we just made the tearDown implementation never fail.

tearDown() is called after each test, so in the event say we needed to
delete records that were added, if they didn't exist in the db due to the
test failing, tearDown() would go ahead and attempt to delete them, but
not fail if they didn't exist.

Now often times when getting a failing test to fail, we'll leave the
tearDown() implementation commented out for a while to get the code
written to pass the test. Then once the test is passing put the
tearDown() implementation back in and leave it. We've done this alot with
tests that do a binary diff on golden data, like a pdf report.

Run the test with tearDown() commented out.
Visually inspect the generated report once, if good save as our golden
data.
Turn on tearDown() and have the test diff against the golden data.

Hope this helps a bit...


On Fri, 3 Jan 2003, Brian <br524@...> wrote:

> No, you have a good point.
>
> The problem is that my test writes to the database, then I call the
> method that I'm unit testing which performs several database functions
> within a transaction, then I read from the database again to test the
> values. The test could fail at any one of these three points.
>
> Your suggestion of cleaning up code though made me look at the
> transactional method I was testing though...it turns out I was missing
> a rollback() call, so thanks! But that still doesn't solve the
> problem I have with three points of failure within my test. If you
> have any ideas as to how to get around this, I'm all ears.
>
